questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft Office 365 subscription that contains default policies only.
The company has the departments and teams shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to recommend which policies must be created to meet the following requirements:
✑ Users in the HR department must be prevented from sending messages marked as Urgent.
✑ Users in the finance department must be able to send messages marked as Urgent.
✑ Users in the finance department must be able to delete sent messages.
The solution must only affect the HR department users and the finance department users.
What is the minimum number of policies you should recommend creating?

choices.B: one messaging policy and one permission policy

comments.content:
"The solution must only affect the HR department users and the finance department users."
So what about Sales then?
Default messaging policy applied to Sales Dept.

discussion.content:
Finance depart is already covered under Default
So you need just one messaging policy

comments.content: So since the default policy is in place, you create an additional messaging policy. Therefore, minimum of 2 policies are created
The default policy is not *created* it already exists
Yes. We need one messaging policy only for HR
Option E makes more sense as HR Dept only needs a Messaging policy rest all requirements are covered under default global policy.

discussion.content: Actually i would go with E on this question, because the requirements for the finance department are already met by default with the Global Messaging policy, so you would only need to create a policy for the HR department
answer is A

One messaging policy.

By default (Global messaging policy) includes all requirements for Finance Dept.
The question is how many additional policy should we create?

The answer is just ONE.
We should create new messaging policy for HR Dept.

How about Sales Dept.?
Global Meeting Policy applied to them. Seems like no requirement for them so that would be clear.

Selected Answer: A
A CORRECT

Selected Answer: E
By Default users can 1. send a message 2. send urgent message using priority notifications so Finance users will be covered under default messaging policy.
So wee need to create only one custom messaging policy for HR.

Selected Answer: E
It should be only one, as Global (Org-Wide Default) Messaging policy sets “priority notifications” and “Delete sent messages” On by default, so it’s already applied.

Selected Answer: E
The answer is E.

By default, the finance department can be able to send messages marked as Urgent. So you only just need 1 policy.

E is correct
They should be prevented from sending messages marked as urgent remember!

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

should be A. The question is what is the min number of policies you need created. So you need two for each department. In addition, it was not specified if other departments outside of Finance and HR can send Urgent messages. So we assume you modify the global policy to prevent that

comments.content: The question states What is the minimum number of policies you should recommend creating. In this instance you would recommend creating 1 policy to cover HR requirements. The rest is in the Default Global.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Default Global Messaging policy allows User to Delete Sent Messages and Send Urgent messages... by default. Only one policy is required.

Selected Answer: A
Should be A

Selected Answer: E
Finance already covered by default policy. Create new messaging policy for HR

Selected Answer: E
Default policy covers the finance department, for both requirements, thus only one policy is needed to satisfy the request of "minimum number of policies you should recommend creating" << creating is the key here.

Selected Answer: A
It should be two. By modifying the default, you are affecting sales and one of the reqs is that it should affect only Finance and HR.

Selected Answer: E
The finance department uses the default policy, it only needs a messaging policy for the HR department
Was on test on 22.08.2022

Selected Answer: A
It has to be A because "The solution must only affect the HR department users and the finance department users." Therefore you cannot change the default policy.

comments.content: I think this question is meant to trip you up a little bit. The company only has default policies so you don't actually need to configure anything for Finance to function as is stated. While obviously not the best solution for a real company that wants specific policies applied to the Finance department, given the current setup, the minimum number of policies required to accomplish the task is one.

discussion.content: On Test 29.03.22
Question is whether the ability to delete messages is covered by default..then you dont need a messaging policy for finance

Selected Answer: A
If i get the question on the exam i would go for answer A because of the following:
*affect Finance & HR
*a default policy can be diffrent as the standard org-wide policy. It's the default for all other users in the company

Selected Answer: E
Option E

Selected Answer: E
We need just one policy for HR.
Global Policy is enough for finance.

Selected Answer: E
Since the question mentioned "Default Policies", then I would go by E. Finance is covered by Default. HR would need a new policy.
On Test 18.01.22

comments.content: So sounds like everyone is saying that "Default messaging Policy" is 3 different policies. One default for Sales, one default for Finance, and one default for HR. Therefore, we are creating custom policy to meet HR? - I don't think this is the case, I would think default would be across all teams, instead of having to go into each team to change its default setting

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
E - the finance department's needs are already set in the default messaging policy.

Selected Answer: E
E
One policy for HR department and all others are covered by global policy

comments.content: Wanted to say E... To bad - there is no DELETE button.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Agree.
Global by default allows send Urgent messages and delete Send messages + question states that it uses DEFAULT policies.
So we only need to create one which will prevent HR users to send Urgent messages.

Microsoft Office 365 subscription that contains default policies only - untouched. 
Otherwise it would be worded "contains org-wide policies only". E for me.

comments.content: Wanted to say E for this one. Wish I could delete

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Going with A on this one
Wording says only affect HR and Finance, which is why A is correct. The Global Messaging policy, while not doing anything, does affect Sales.

The solution must only affect the HR department users and the finance department users.
due to this statement, I will go for A.

As the question doesn't tell you what the default policies are, we can't assume that they are the same as what finance needs. It would show you pictures of settings if they wanted you to analyse current setup.
https://www.examtopics.com/exams/microsoft/ms-700/view/22/#2 messaging polices is the right answer in my opinion.

As the question doesn't tell you what the default policies are, we can't assume that they are the same as what finance needs. It would show you pictures of settings if they wanted you to analyse current setup.
2 messaging polices is the right answer in my opinion.

Users in the HR department must be prevented from sending messages marked as Urgent. - Custom policy
Users in the finance department must be able to send messages marked as Urgent. - Global default
Users in the finance department must be able to delete sent messages. - Global default

Create one custom policy, and apply it to HR
Leave Global Org-wide as is

comments.content: We don't know anything about the current Global, so we cannot start with its default values. But regardless of this, it affects Sales, so we cannot go with it, I guess.

for the Finance and Sales policy stays default. Finance requires to send marked as urgent and delete sent messages (that's default setting), therefor I won't see any reason to create more than one policy only. Or am I missing something?

discussion.content: There are 3 departments that are mentioned here. To ensure Sales is not affected, we need to create a policy for HR and another for Finance. Thus 2 messaging policies is the right answer.
Correct Answer

yes,no,no
Owner will not see private channel in the left navigation sidebar, but can enter the team's settings and then see all active and deleted channels, the channel type and the owers of private channels
Wow...A team owner can not see the members of a private channel in a team they own...I must keep that in mind...

I tested in my test tenant about files. I have the owner of private team named A and a channel created by owner B. The owner A can see and modify the file created by B. Why did u select NO in the second question about the file ? Thanks.
YES,NO,NO

Answer is correct Yes , No , No.
Just tested this in the lab.
Was on test on 22.08.2022
answers are correct, however the pictures are not in the right order.
On Test 29.03.22

Y,n,n
Tested and verified

Should be NO/NO/NO

Team owners can see the names of all private channels in their team and can also delete any private channel in the team. (A deleted private channel can be restored within 30 days after it's deleted). Team owners can't see the files in a private channel or the conversations and member list of a private channel unless they are members of that private channel.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/private-channels

comments.content:

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains a group named Group1.
You need to configure Group1 to meet the following requirements:
✑ Users must not be permitted to pin apps to the Microsoft Teams app bar.
✑ Only the Chat, Teams, and Calendar apps must appear on the Microsoft Teams app bar.
Which policy type should you create and which PowerShell cmdlet should you run to assign the policy? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
This one makes sense, create a custom app setup policy, then grant it to the users in Group1

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/teams-app-setup-policies#edit-an-app-setup-policy

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/skype/grant-csteamsappsetuppolicy?view=skype-ps
App permission does not exist anymore, that is moved to manage apps. Given answers are correct.
customisation and configuration are setup features. this alone rules out all of the wrong answer choices

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to prevent temporary employees from using the private chat feature in Microsoft Teams.
Solution: You create an app permission policy and assign the policy to the users.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Messaging policy

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B

Selected Answer: B
duh...
Messaging policy - not app policy. Answer is correct.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-US/microsoftteams/supervise-chats-edu#define-chat-permission-roles-for-each-user-in-your-environment

questions.question_text:
Your company has a Microsoft 365 subscription that contains 200 Microsoft Teams users and 20 teams.
You discover that several teams do NOT have an owner.
You need to ensure that you receive a notification when a team is missing an owner.
What should you do?

choices.C: From the Azure Active Directory admin center, modify the group expiration settings.
choices.D: From PowerShell, run the Add-AzureADMSLifecyclePolicyGroup cmdlet.
choices.A: From the Microsoft Teams admin center, modify the Teams settings.
choices.B: From PowerShell, run the Set-Team cmdlet.

discussion.content:
Ans. is C

"Provide an email address where expiration notifications should be sent when a group has no owner"

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/enterprise-users/groups-quickstart-expiration#set-group-expiration

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C
the key phrase here is "receive a notification". this should point you to group expiration settings
Trick question - Answer is C - However, Expiration settings does not have an option to notify you if a team is missing a owner. You will still have to go find the teams without owners.

Selected Answer: C
Confirm C
AAD - Groups - Settings - Expiration - Email contact for groups with no owners
Ryrvhh
